reviewText:
At first glance Magicka will look like a fun button mashing experience to have with your friends. If you look further you will see that there is more enjoyment to experience from Magicka than you could ever see from the trailers and screenshots. Magicka has created something that no game had ever done before (at least not well). From just a combination of buttons you can create powerful spells that bare strategy behind them. Of course there are a number of downsides and bugs to this game that when overlooked barely interfere with the gameplay at all and will usually result in a laugh. Make no mistakes, this game is for pure fun and joy.

If you are looking for a game to play with your friends then look no further because this game is precisely what you need. You are getting a lot more fun out of this game than the price would intend you to believe. At such a low price you get hours of gameplay excluding all of the tremendous amount of downloadable content. Magicka is a co-op game that brings out the evil inside you and your friends. You can be on your way to defeating the infamous Grimnir when out beaming behind you is a beam of arcane from your companion aiming directly for you. Magicka really brings out the troll in most people and with countless of opportunities to kill you your friends will never get bored killing you and reviving you, killing and reviving you, killing and... yeah.

For the serious competitors that don't like the limitations that Magicka: Wizard Wars gives you but are still interested in the humor and game mechanics of Magicka then the pvp or challenge modes will prove to be very effective gamemodes. As stated before Magicka has a very diverse field of strategy. For example someone will be coming at you with some fire so you have to quickly decide to cast a fire shield onto yourself to become immune to fire and then come at them with the most unexpected attacks in order to win a player versus player match. Challenge mode also includes some strategy and competition. Once you die in challenge you're done for and must start from square one. This means you can compete against your friends and see who is the greater wizard.

Now I bring you the bugs, glitches and problems this game faces. The bugs in this game are usually hilarious to see happen to someone you are playing with and usually funny to watch when they happen to you. These are the small bugs that don't affect you in a huge way when playing Magicka but through your playthrough it is not unlikely to come across a big glitch that will require you to restart the game and have you go back to the last checkpoint. Another thing that could be considered a problem in this game is it's massive amount of downloadable content which could possibly be a deal breaker for you if you just hate paying just a bit extra for a full package. What I must reassure you with is the fact that none of the extra content is required to feel whole although it is a bit depressing when you look at your robes and see a horde of robes unable to play with. When it comes to actual level and gameplay dlc Paradox have done something I must praise them for. When playing online only the host needs the downloadable content in order to play it so essentially you could play every dlc level without ever paying a cent.

This was the first game I had in my library and it's what got me interested in steam. So as someone who has had their lives changed (or ruined from the access to almost every modern pc game developed) I say buy this game whenever you get the chance. If you're interested in humour, magick, wizards, co-op, being a troll, strategic moves, unstrategic fails, using powerful combos that wipes everything off the screen causing you all to go back to the start of the game, competition or vampires that think no one knows that they are vampires then I highly recommend to try this game out regardless if you're a loner and can't find anyone to play it with.

Updated Review.

One of the most fun spellcasting systems I have ever seen! Knowing what to cast in what situation has never been more satisfying. The concept itself of combining elements to make spells had me sold, and the game itself managed to value that potential.

The freedom of doing whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want whenever you want is amazing. No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t mana bars. No crappy skill trees. No cooldowns. Pure, unaltered, raw power, scaled with your skill level. Some DBZ style ♥♥♥♥ here.

There are downsides though:
- arrowhead did one of the crappiest netcodes in existence. Crashes happen. Connections don't. Hosting doesn't work most of the time. Multiplayer is such an amazing experience, be it Adventure, Challenge or Versus and crap like this stands in the way. If you can overlook that, this game is easily a 88/100, but with the crappy 1998 multiplayer, the score is rightfully dragged down to 74.
- latency in this game is on steroids for some reasons, probably bad optimization
- too few people play, and because of the crappy matchmaking system you need to know people's numbers and have friends that play
- they pump out a ton of DLCs, something that I hate on principle
- the devs aren't really fixing much. They're adding more stuff and grabbing lodsemoneh
- limited to a max of 4 players per game (and I think having way more would've been so much fun; game is not made for this)

The PROS:
- the combinations you can do with those 8 elements is mindblowing
- so much fun in all 3 modes: Adventure, Challenge and especially Versus if you are at a high skill level and monsters are too weak
- skill level can be INSANE. One guy can take out 100 other wizards and 1000 mobs, without getting a scratch.
- single player is a lot of fun: comedic story, fun missions, DLCs aren't bad, they're just short
- various robes you can put on, with various abilities
- at high levels of play, the PVP aspect is balanced, but at low-med levels, you can spam a few spells and always win since people don't know how to counter them
- Versus mode is LODSA fun at high skill levels
- huge skill roof
- great physics and offense-defense mechanics
- intuitive effects of your spells

I recommend it a lot, especially if it's on sale. About the DLCs? I'm not sure. Having the base game is enough imo, the DLCs are really worth it for the extra robes that you can have fun with.

reviewText:
Magicka is one of my favorite games, and one of the few that does a good job making you feel like a wizard.


The Good:

The crown jewel of Magicka's design is its spell creation system.  It was not the first video game to allow you to design spells by selecting the path, area of effect, effects, and intensities.  The Elder Scrolls: Arena had that in 1994, and there may be earlier examples I don't know about.  It may be the first to allow you to create spells on the fly.  It is also noteworthy for having no limits based on a mana pool or cooldowns.  Instead, the main balancing forces are enemy resistances and the destructive power of your own spells.  It's very easy to make a mistake and kill yourself or your allies.

Magicka is also well known and loved for its voice acting.  Everyone speaks a mix of broken Swedish and jibberish.  Vlad is an over the top Romanian vampire in denial.  Death and Fafnir also sound great.  I would love to know what sort of processing they performed on their voices.

Magicka has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard.  It's bombastic, complex, and memorable.  Unfortunately it may be hard to appreciate with it often being drowned out by the sounds of the chaos around you.


The Bad:

Magicka is very buggy, even by modern PC gaming standards.  Crashes and hangs are common.  Weapons and staves, which may be unique, frequently clip through the map and disappear into the void forever.  Players lose connection in online games often.  The DLC is even worse.  The Stars Are Left has an unpatched bug on the last level, where if you don't pass through the doors in the order the developers expected you to, not only does it crash, but it corrupts your save so you have to start that DLC over.  The fact that is still unpatched is shameful, by the way.

Difficulty does not scale based on the number of players.  The main game isn't that difficult to get through solo, but some of the DLC is very hard without a full party.  I found the final fights in Dungeons and Daemons and The Stars Are Left to be impossible to solo.

I don't think I've ever been so in love with a video game before...

It's buggy, horribly optimized, and suffers from such bad models and animations that they make a joke of it (traveling through landscapes that showcase herds of sheep-facades propped up in the pastures, or riding upon noble steeds who seem to be from the finest wooden toy horse stock), and you won't give a damn about any of it.  The multiplayer is nearly impossible to set up and laggy almost to the point of unplayability once you do, but it's such vibrant, stupid and chaotic fun that you'll ignore such minor negatives in favor of the grander scheme of bumbling wizards.

The innovative magic system is profoundly complex and joyously destructive to experiment with, and there's a very scientific glee involved with working out your trademark spell(s) or finding the coolest combinations to solve a particular problem.

You'll also learn to develop a newfound respect for such veterans of the wizardry craft as Gandalf or Dumbledore...  When you recognize just how much obscenely destructive force you have at your unwitting fingertips, it's always impressive when you DON'T manage to disintegrate/melt yourself and everyone in a 4-mile radius when attempting to do something.

While the game is fun enough on its own and the writing is of absolutely stellar class, with actually funny wit and some really quite unexpectedly subtle jokes and twists, this game excels at multiplayer.  Yes, the horribly-irritating-to-get-started multiplayer.

My deepest recommendation is to play this game with 3 friends, preferably with none of you knowing your wizard staves from your rump bristles.  Idiocy and a vast array of destructive weaponry often lead to the best of times, and ignorance of your own strength is the perfect excuse for accidentally" slaughtering everyone on your team.

The 76 metascore is the result of what Magicka was when it came out: A hidden gem executed okey-ishly and with some bugs. But that's way too far from the game Magicka is today...

Which is one of the best Local-Multiplayer/Co-Op/Versus games in all of Steam. I was a late buyer so I got to skip all the supposed bug-fest, but let me tell you this: Right now, Magicka is a blast to play with friends. Be it local or online multiplayer, co-op campaign or versus or survival, with keyboards or with controllers or any mix of all of the above.

Aside from the super-robust level of multiplayer options, the game's campaigns (main and all of the DLCs) are amazing. The main campaign is filled with easter eggs, little details everywhere and stupendous and magnificent narrative comedy. I'll be frank and admit I haven't finished most DLCs yet (as I wait until all my buds can get together to finish them in one sitting), but I can tell you that The Stars Are Left, The Other Side of the Coin and Dungeons And Daemons are worth every penny.

The quality for your money also applies for multiplayer-oriented DLC, which is cheap and adds lots of cool themes, robes with different stats and abilities and weapons that range from The Doctor's Screwdriver to Ak-47s and of course a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amount of staffs.

Where to start, where to start...
The insanely intricate magic system that offers a crazy amount of different spell combinations? The quirky humour that is cram-packed with references to popular culture and everything geek? The endearing colourful graphics that turn every second of looking at this game into pure joy? Or maybe the never-ending challenges, be it through several great DLCs or the long list of fun achievements? Because yes, this game, unlike so many, offers achievements that are actually that, real achievements that are either painfully challenging or simply extremely fun to get.
Yet of course, while Magicka offers all that, it only truly unfolds its full potential when played with others. Personally I enjoy co-op most (accidental, yet sometimes not so unintentional, killing of your friends guaranteed thanks to friendly fire), but versus mode as well offers a good deal of entertainment.
There is literally no excuse not to get and enjoy Magicka if you like video games and most certainly a bunch of good laughs.

Again, there's no cost to resurrecting your friends, but some players could become frustrated from being killed by their friends more than their enemies.  $10 is well worth a game like this, so grab your friends and see how well you work together!

reviewText:
In Magicka, you're a wizard. You've got eight elements that you can stack up, mix, multiply, and unleash. You can cast them at goblins, cast them at anything next to you, cast them at your specially blunted sword, cast them at your own face.

Singleplayer mode is a light comic fantasy, narrated by your dodgy mentor, Vlad. The black-clad Romanian wizard keeps pointing out that he's not a vampire, and making bad puns about sinking his teeth into things. It's a mix of satire and pop culture references that'll have you smirking dangerously throughout.


Lots of care has gone into the way the elements combine and contort in your spells. Combinations shape the form (Missile? Beam? Cone? Wall?) and function (Healing? Burning? Shielding? Exploding? Freezing? Drenching? Zapping?) of each glorious experiment. There's enough variety for every wizard to have his or her own favourite attack style. Mine is a steamy lightning beam that scalds you before dealing bonus lightning damage from the water element in steam.

Concocting these spells is a little confusing at first, as you're commanding eight elements across eight keys, but you're rarely faced with enemies that can't be killed by particular elements. Button mashing will get you far, and a mistake might just surprise you.


The environments are top-down, linear jaunts through bright and breezy fantasy tropes: forests full of goblins, orcish trenches, swamps, mines, the land of the dead. Wander off the beaten path, and you can find powerful equipment and new magic spell recipes that reach beyond the scope of your regular elemental concoctions - spells such as Revive and Teleport.

Singleplayer will soon wear thin, sadly. It's not that you can't beat it with the right spells and an awful lot of goes – it's that if you make a mistake and burst like a sticky water balloon, you get chucked back to the last checkpoint you reached. In once case, that involves fighting three big groups of face-pounding orcs and one-hit-smash-to-deathing ogres, in a row, before you hit another checkpoint. If you quit before you complete that level (perhaps out of, ooh, say, frustration), you'll have to start it all over again when you boot up the game again. Ultimately, you'll hit this annoying boss or that overpowered yeti thing or this boring underworld level and you'll just give up on singleplayer. Then you'll turn to multiplayer.


And multiplayer is good, when it works. If you've got a few networked computers and three eager friends with Magicka on their Steam accounts, you can enjoy the splendour of four death lasers combining neatly into a super-beam that bursts ogres in seconds. You can have tactics and gambits and laugh as they end with one wizard left, deciding if he wants your gear before he resurrects you.

The bulk of us, however, will be butting our heads against the brick wall of online multiplayer. At the time of writing, developers Arrowhead have been releasing patches every 24 hours, and they're gradually improving on the terrible connectivity issues. Despite their efforts, you no sooner host a game than Steam Chat dies, Skype calls drop, and flatmates start inspecting the router for flashing lights. For a game so reliant on multiplayer to be fun, there are lots of missed opportunities. There's no chapter select function, no joining mid-session for latecomers or disconnected players, no voice chat, no dedicated servers, and tons of lengthy, wordy cutscenes that only the host can skip.


Get it working, and it's great. For £8, you'll get your money's worth before everyone forgets about it. But it could have been game of the year material! Silly wizards.

THE VERDICT
69/100
MAGICKA
Confused and buggy, but very entertaining under the right circumstances. Bring friends.

reviewText:
This is another very long review. If you just want a summary of my reasons for why I recommend this game skip to Results and read from there.

Magicka by Arrowhead Game Studios is an interesting game that really keeps you on your toes. I use the word interesting because this game has some great concepts although I could easily see them as potential weaknesses to some people. Magicka requires you to use physics and chemistry to create spells and solve puzzles. These include such concepts as freezing rivers, powering generators, and combining elements to create powerful spells.

The Campaign:
You play as one of four wizards who are a part of the Order of Magick. You start their adventure in Castle Alderheim where you are given a quest to save the world. The game includes twelve chapters, which pull you through time and space. You are led by your guide Vlad, possibly a vampire, who continuously points you in the right direction. The campaign requires you to fight many bosses who require different tactics to beat: Jormungandr, Jotunn, The Warlock, Khan, Grimnir, The Aristocrats, Vlad, Death, Fafnir, Grimnir, and Assatur. There are many DLC packs which allow you to play many campaigns and experience a full new game. The campaign has funny dialogue which speaks between English and gibberish. The campaign is rather cut and dry. Each level is essentially the same concept, basically fight the enemies and beat the level. Yet again, this is how most games that fit into this genre seem to be. There are many funny jokes, references, and characters which make this game a blast to play through. In fact one of the Wizards you can select is a Space Marine from the 40k series (plus there are all these game references in the campaign).

Gameplay:
The enemies tend to repeat themselves and throughout the campaign you typically be using the same spells over again. What most people don’t seem to mention is the difficulty of this game. This game is not easy in any sense of the word, in fact even if you play with more people the game just gets harder. With latency issues and friendly fire can result in a very tough campaign where you will kill your friends more than your enemies. If you play the game solo it can be very difficult and with the patches and updates is even harder now than it was before. There is no mana, no leveling up, and pretty much no real loot. You may find a few weapons throughout the campaign, but they are not going to make a huge difference to how you play the campaign. I personally played the whole game with the M60, but other than that all the weapons seemed to be just as effective as the ones I start with.

Useful Advice:
Magicka REQUIRES a good keyboard. This keyboard preferably should be a gaming keyboard and should not be wireless (unless it’s a wireless gaming keyboard). In order to preform spells and move at the same time Magicka sometimes requires you to use more keys than you have fingers. If your keyboard cannot handle multiple key-presses then you will not be able to play this game. I would recommend playing this game with a macro-enabled keyboard/mouse in order to fully enjoy the actual campaign. In fact the game can be so difficult that even with macros you will more than likely not succeed in a mission on your first attempt. There are many spell combinations with some of them being very hard to figure out.

Results:
If you like bird’s eye view co-op action adventures then this could be a good choice for you. Make sure you are well equipped, ready for a hard challenge, and have some friends. This is a fun campaign, with witty dialogue, and amazing spell casting. If you have a great memory for up to eight letter combinations then you’ll be very good at this game. If I were you I’d play the game with macros, essentially that’s like putting the game from “Insane” down to “Hard Difficulty”.

Pros:
+Spell combinations are almost endless
+Funny dialogue, hilarious references, and a great story.
+Many items you can find in the game (with different bonuses and special spells)
+Lots of wizards to select from with different weapons and base attributes
+Offers four player co-op experience
+Nice graphics and smooth visuals
+Interesting boss fights which require a variety of different strategies
+Puzzles and mysteries to solve within each level
+Lots of DLC with new story and characters abound
+Rather long campaign
+NO GRINDING

Cons:
-Insanely difficult (especially if you solo or co-op without experts).
-Spell combinations can be rather cumbersome (not a game for people who are not good with memorizing eight letter combinations).
-If you are not an expert at memory you typically end up using the same spell through the entire game (rock, rock, rock, rock, rock).
-I sometimes had issue with random lag in the main menu screen (nothing game-breaking, but could get infuriating sometimes).

reviewText:
Ah, Magicka, one of the most disappointing games in recent memory, in my opinion. While I do love the game for it's atmosphere and general humor, there are glaring shortcomings with the game that hurt it.

The positive side - the humor and pacing of the story is done very well in my opinion, and Vlad's constant sarcasm and satire punctuate things quite well. While short, the story is just meaty enough to be satisfying and the writer(s) pulled off the 'stable time loop' thing rather well - props to them, where it's deserved.

The negative side - oi, where to start?

The casting system. While at first the QWERASF casting system seems fluent enough, the ability of the system to be easily and ergodynamically used under pressure of heated gameplay flounders. For most people (read: non-pro players), heated combat turns into mashing a few powerful, simple combo (such as SDFSDF) repeatedly, if not just mashing the keyboard period. The casting system also suffers from some other problems, which will be mentioned ancedotally below.

Optimisation - I'll be honest: this game isn't optimized for ♥♥♥♥. I have an $1800 gaming rig, not even a year old, and even it gets knocked beneath 20 fps on a regular basis. This hurts - not only does this kill immersion and throw off your ability to maneuvor and position yourself correctly, but the frame skip can wreck your ability to cast. I cannot count how many times I missed an important element in a long combo because my game hiccuped and lost 15fps for a split second.

Multiplayer - Oh boy. Multiplayer in Magicka can be summed up, really, as pay to win. The netcode, coupled with the above-mentioned optimization issues, turns into a flustercuck of laggy, desyncronized chaos. Additionally, some of the paid robes offer massive advantages over the free ones - the biggest offender is the 'Assassin Robe', I think it was - 50% of the regular life, but he runs around twice as fast and comes with a poisoned crossbow to boot, as well as an emergency teleport backwards. This guy in particular is horribly unbalanced - he's so fast most things don't even damage him, and a player mistake that leaves him vulnerable can mostly be avoided by the emergency teleport thanks to the copious cover on most multiplayer maps. He's horribly broken, damned near impossible to kill, and more than capable of making exceedingly fatal hit and run attacks with impunity.

Design direction - Really, I can't tell where the devs were going with Magicka. The easy death, and equally easy revive that get's pushed down your throat both basically force you to play co-op (you're a squishy bugger by yourself, and you can't be revived either. Nevermind that the game doesn't scale for single-player play...), and the aforementioned mechanics and general air of the game make it feel something like a LAN party game, almost like an overglorified, gory Mario Party spinoff. On the other hand, the casting system and pace of combat, at times, feel like they were going for a hardcore combat game with tight tolerances and no room for mistakes. This shift becomes brutally painful right around the dwarven caves level, which in my opinion is basically the 'stop-having-fun' level (if you've tried soloing it, hell even trying it with a single partner, you'll understand why)

Clarity in Combat - this is arguably more of a personal one, but I found that in the heat of battle I had a difficult time identifying enemy units whilst trying to mash out complex combos. More over, I found that the wet and burning status debuffs killed me more often than anything - it's not directly clear, from a glance, that you're wet/on fire, it doesn't jump out at you, the wet effect in particular. With the effect of trying to channel lightning when wet being rather disasterous, it becomes a point of pure aggrivation when you die simply because there's too much ♥♥♥♥ going on at once to keep track of all the little details like that, again especially considering they dont' really jump out at you.

In all, while I really do enjoy Magicka and personally find it halarious, I cannot, really, recommend this game to anybody. In fact, I would whole-heartly tell people to avoid it like the plague unless you can overlook all the glaring, broken elements of this game (pardon the pun).

reviewText:
Magicka is an extremely fresh take on a very tired genre. The top-down Action RPG. It replaces the standard combat with one of the most innovative spell casting system I've ever seen in a game. Eight different elements that can be combined and used in a myriad of logical and easy to understand ways. Firing lightning at your enemies is more effective if you dose them with water first, combining cold and water makes you shoot ice shards and so on. It is easy to learn and easy to use even if some of the higher tier spells require a bit of practice.

The graphics are simple but functional and the sound is somewhat lacking, the characters speaking some perverted form of Finnish mixed in with a good deal of gibberish.

The storyline and characters are as random as it gets and the entire game is filled to the rim with old pop culture references. A little fun but not much, this is a game that should be played for the gameplay and nothing else.

A great buy, especially with friends.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Magicka
Original Release: 2011
Genre Tags: RPG; Action; Innovative; Lighthearted; Fantasy
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 9-20 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Optional
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Novelty seekers
REVIEWMagicka is a very enjoyable game. Fun, funny, and challenging... it makes for a very amusing experience. The standard campaign is relatively brief, but there is a lot of DLC content. Some of it is cosmetic and can be ignored, but much of it provides actual content and you will likely want to pick it up to get the full experience. Magicka also makes for unique and enjoyable multiplayer gameplay, if you find some people to play with.

As I alluded to, the innovation inherent in the main gameplay mechanics is the primary reason that Magicka is something worthy of being in your library. There isn’t much else quite like it, and absolutely nothing of the same caliber.  You have to rapidly press certain button combinations to cast various spells while simultaneously controlling your character and aiming in an isometric view. It is pretty unique and intense. I personally found it more comfortable with a controller, but it also works well with a standard keyboard and mouse set up.

And while the exciting gameplay is definitely the soul of the game, it is also quite funny and charming too. The art style is very fitting to the mood of the game; and although the graphics aren’t the best, they feel appropriate. With the addition of the mumble language, silly plot, and hyperbole of blood/gore, the jovial nature of Magicka becomes clear. This lighthearted atmosphere synergizes well with the unique gameplay to create an experience that is incontestably fun.

The key feature of the game being the innovative gameplay mechanics, I recommend anyone looking for some variety check it out if they haven’t already. I highly recommend playing with other people though; it’s much more fun and much less frustrating (since you can revive each other).

Also the Versus and Survival modes are pretty fun, especially since the game supports local-coop (as in sitting on a couch with your friends, as it was in the old days).

An innovative and refreshing Fantasy RPG that does not take itself seriously.
Magicka is an RPG in the spirit of Gauntlet, except there is only one class: Wizard.
In this reality, Wizards possess infinite power and do not run out of Mana - you only need to worry about running out of Health.
It can be played solo or with up to four players.
Multitudes of Robes with different abilties to choose from for everyone's own preferred playstyle.
Each character possesses a Staff and a Side Weapon (Knife, Sword, Gun).

Being a Wizard on the up-and-up, you are still learning, so you must explore to collect Tomes which contain different Magicks.
These Magicks contain the necessary element combinations to perform incredible conjurings of powerful efficaciousness.
It will take practice, it will take skill. You will die...alot. You will kill your friends...alot.

The journey ahead is filled with foes big and small, ferocious and...world conquering. But the journey ahead is also an enigma - you must write your own destiny...rise above the challenges and become the most powerful Wizard in all The Land!

reviewText:
Wizards have always been in a rut when it comes to games. They're portrayed as miracle workers; quick-witted masters of arcane elements. What wizards are handled as, though, are simple glass cannons -- frail men with a limited attack pool governed by arbitrary numbers and points. The player is forced to forsee several actions and plan ahead, all to achieve the same effectiveness as the burly fighters who charge headfirst into the fray like a bloodthirsty, brain-dead zombie.

Magicka is the first game I've played to do wizarding right. Magicka puts you in the role of a rookie wizard, and you progress through the game not by leveling up or watching a magic meter, but through experimenting with combining the eight elements you are given, much like you would expect a real wizard to. What happens when you mix fire and water? Does lightning do more damage than earth? Can you add cold to this spell to make it more effective? You can use all elements infinitely, so the only limit to what you do is what you have yet to try.

That's just the casting mechanics. Mix it in with the tongue-in-cheek style of the world of Midgard, based on Scandinavian mythology and driven by pop-culture references. This game has many moments, from hilarious tributes to many fandoms to the excitement of perfecting your favorite spell. It was well worth my time and money.

This game's pretty straightforward as far as the story goes, but the number of combinations of magicks and the skill required in order to kill the increasingly tougher horde/bosses makes it very fun at times. The fact that you can cross opposite beams to kill enemies when they're healing each other is really cool, as well as the increase in strength proportional to the complexity and number of spells used. Also the idea of using opposites, like casting water on an enemy then using lightning to double the damage done, makes the game really strategic. This game can be REALLY frustrating though. Dying 10 times at the exact same  point in the story because you're outnumbered and there are enemies that are casting OP beams constantly is a little rough. But again, although it seems impossible at times, there is a strategy. Sometimes that strategy is using your own OP beams *cough* lightning bolt *cough* or mines or any other such magick and those may make otherwise difficult and time-consuming bosses or large enemies really easy to kill. After I do that, I'm satisfied that i've finally gotten past a hard point in the story but I don't really have the satisfaction of working for it. Magicka is an action-adventure game set in a rich fantasy world based on Norse mythology. The player assumes the role of a wizard from a sacred order tasked with the ultimate goal of stopping an evil sorcerer who has thrown the world into turmoil, his evil creations besieging the forces of good.
The rich, luscious colors somehow make the world a lot more believable than games like Crysis 2 could ever be.
People have complained that Magicka is too complex or confusing, but they're missing the point. It's a game about wielding immense power, but having to be clever to use it properly.
Anyone who has any interest in cooperative games or action-adventure would do well to pick it up, especially for the almost ridiculous price of $10.

eines Zauberers, der entweder mit 3 Freunden oder alleine die Welt vor den bösen Zauberer Grimnir retten muss.

Einige Elemente kann man auch selber zusammenfügen und so eigene Zauber erfinden. Und wenn man mal keine Zeit hat zum zaubern, oder einen einfach der Platz fehlt, kann man die Gegner mit seiner Handwaffe erledigen.
Das Waffen Arsenal reicht vom normalen Schwert bis hin zur modernen Uzi, welcher der Spieler auch nochmal verzaubern kann und so mehr Schaden anzurichten.

Die Highlights im Spiel sind die vielen kleinen versteckten Anlehnungen an berühmte Filme und Spiele wie Star Wars, Ritter der Kokosnuss, The Legend of Zelda, WOW, oder Matrix.

You're a group of unstable wizards with infinite power, get through the enemies whilst trying to not set yourself or your friends on fire. G'luck.

Majicka is a game about questions, do you want to set this on fire? Do you want to slap a goblin with an enchanted ice sword as large as a baby skyscraper? Do you want to melt your friend's face, revive him, and melt his face again? These are just a small sampling of soulful questions that Majicka will pose to you, but perhaps you are a busy man with no time for trivia. Majicka can also make full-fledged statements. Ensconcing enemies in ice and flinging a rock at their vulnerable frozen forms will make it Wizard Christmas. Wizard Christmas is just like regular Christmas except Wizard Christmas snow is sometimes red and the only suitable present for a wizard is cheese.



So if you enjoy seeing your enemies driven before you with weeping and gnashing of teeth do not buy this game.



On the other hand if you enjoy helping a friend blow up a golem before using your mighty powers, derived from the deepest depths of Arcana to gently push him off a ledge while cackling madly, then buy this game, and buy a copy for your friend. Then find a new friend once he swears eternal vengeance upon you.

A mage is walking through a village and sees a woman standing outside of her house with an exclamation mark over her head, and approaches her to talk.  She asks him to deal with rats in her basement.  And in that moment, RPG veterans would groan from all of the times they were given the same mindless tasks, and these aren't even cranium rats!

But of course, there is a twist here.  Everything in this game takes a comedic dump on RPG conventions, lead by a narrator who is totally not a vampire.  What kind of game is this?  It's the kind of game with a Vietnam expansion where you use a M60 on goblins.  Awkwardness of that expansion aside, this is a rather geeky parody of the RPG genre, in the vein of games like Munchkin that find humor in the genre itself.  It's also in Swedish, which gives it an unusual feel.

The game features a unique magic system, in which eight elements are used in combinations that create spells.  Combining some elements create new elements (such as fire and water making steam), while others cancel each other out.  Learning the combinations that create spells is the key to the game, and it becomes vital to learn to enter them quickly.  While the game can be played with a gamepad, a keyboard and mouse are more effective because they allow faster entry of spells.  Up to four players can play in co-op.

For many years I had been getting more and more cynical about games actually getting better rather than more corporately profitable. The lack of creative, enjoyable multiplayer games was quite noticable in comparison to the time of Rune, Greebles, Super Maze Wars and other such titles. And then...
Suddenly, Magicka.

Magicka is the answer to all this. It has a delicious innovatively smooth multiplayer integration and has a combat system that is, whilst less innovative, so creative and creatively stimulating that its smooth, intricate functionality can only be described as organic.

The overall ambience and atmosphere in Magicka is a chirpy, happy, quirky one. Magicka may very well be the result of all that lacking fun and creativity I mentioned being funneled into one single project, to the extent of the quirkiness and continuous references to other media nearly getting on one's nerves. Nearly.

Definitely recommended. And *definitely* definitely recommended to play with good friends.

I bought Magicka on sale long after its original release, so my recommendation is based on those two qualifications that differ greatly from major publication reviews. I found the game to be (mostly) bug-free and quite enjoyable, with the only serious issue being multiplayer is absolutely lacking players and those that do play tend to have agonizingly high ping (European and South American players maybe!?). The single player is a good experience and worth the price of entry, yet entirely too short. Note that ALL of the DLC is for multiplayer, which is basically unpopulated. Shame really. One thumb up, two if there were more people playing multiplayer.\n\nA month later, and I'm still playing this game almost obsessively. The reason: Challenges. SINGLE PLAYER challenges, because multiplayer is still as crappy as it has ever been - i.e. non-existant. Most players / servers have +300 ping and quit all the time. This game needs drop-in play like Mario needs a jump button, but it doesn't have it. The combination of spells and enemies makes the single-player challenges a worthwhile time-waster, so I keep playing. If only the makers would fix multiplayer, this game would be a 10/10 indie game. Otherwise, even as cheap as it is right now (75% off on Steam), it's still only one thumb up and one way, way down. Single player only for the time being, even during the free-to-play weekend.

Magicka adalah game aksi dengan mekanisme sihir elemen yang cukup asyik dengan tampilan gameplay yang mirip DotA. Tugasmu dalam game ini cukup simpel, yaitu hancurkan monster-monster dengan kekuatan sihirmu, kalahkan boss, dan selesaikan setiap stage yang ada. Yang paling menarik dari game ini adalah mekanisme magic-nya, di mana kamu dapat menggabung-gabungkan 8 elemen sihir yang ada untuk menciptakan sihir yang kuat sesuai situasi dan selera--simpel sekaligus kompleks. Ditambah mekanisme MP/mana tak terbatas, kamu bisa merasakan menjadi penyihir yang kuat.

Cerita Magicka--yang sedari awal sudah konyol, banyak dibumbui parodi ikon pop culture seperti Star Wars, 300, Castlevania, The Hobbit plus bahasa lucu (English+Swedish+gibberish) sehingga menjadikannya semakin konyol lagi.

Sangat menyenangkan untuk dimainkan sendiri ataupun multiplayer (biar bisa saling bunuh antar teman). Oh ya, ingat-ingatlah mantra sakti 'QFASA' dan kalau suntuk jangan lupa 'dunka dunka'. Happy gaming!

English Version

Magicka is an action game with interesting elemental magic mechanism, with gameplay which looks similar to DotA. The objective is fairly simple: defeat your enemies with your mighty magick power, defeat the boss and clear the stage. The most interesting thing about this game is its magic casting mechanism where you can combine the 8 magick elements to produce many kinds of spell best suited to the situation and your personal taste. With unlimited MP/mana, you can truly experience what it feels like to be mighty wizard in fantasy RPG setting (with comedic touch).

The story--which is already funny, is made even funnier with pop culture icon parodies such as Star Wars, 300, Castlevania, The Hobbit, etc. The Simlish-like language (or maybe English+Swedish+Gibberish) is also very funny.

It's a very fun game to play alone or with friends (so you can kill each other 'accidentally'). Also, never forget QFASA and try to do some 'dunka dunka' whenever you get stressed. Happy gaming!

reviewText: Magicka is a mostly cooperative (friendly fire is on) game about combining elements to create magic spells. It supports up to 4 player multiplayer with a adventure, challenge, and versus mode. The way the magic spells work is you have 6 slots to put elements in, and whatever combination you put in is mixed to create a unique spell. There are literally unlimited spell combinations, so there's tons of diversity. There's also books scattered around where you can find these things called Magicks, these are pre-set spells that do special things (some notable ones are summons, vortex, rain/thunderstorm/blizzard, ect). There are also many robes you can select aswell, they have special perks and downsides that make them unique from eachother (like immunity/weakness to some elements). The campaign could last you a good 4-5 hours with added DLC campaigns as well to add on to it. There are A LOT of DLC for this game, mostly PVP maps and robes, these are NOT needed and you should only get them if you feel like you would like those robes/maps or want to support the developer but the campaign DLCs are a must have in my opinion. People say this game is a buggy mess, and it is, but the glitches you may encounter are actually entertaining. The developer have worked hard and patched out most of the game ruining ones, so there's not much to worry about. Get this game, it's worth your money if you have friends to play it with.

reviewText:
Magicka

Magicka is a satirical action-adventure game set in a rich fantasy world based on Norse mythology. The player assumes the role of a wizard from a sacred order tasked with stopping an evil sorcerer who has thrown the world into turmoil, his foul creations besieging the forces of good. Magicka is a brilliant game made on the 25th January 2011 and i have to say...I LOVE THIS GAME. ONE OF THE BEST GAMES IN MY LIBRARY IF NOT, THE BEST.
I am not a big fan of RPG games but Magicka has really made me change my mind. This game is superb. Create Spells with your friends .I think Magicka is probably the best mage-game out there. With its amazing sense of satirical humor, Magicka really does bring out out the laughs very often.  The characters voicing and language is the best there is because the way they speak is so humorous, just like the minions in despicable me.

Pros:
- Fun game that you can play with friends.
- Allows you to do spells that the students of hogwarts can't do.
- Characters Voicing is very funny.

Cons:
- Co-op (Multiplayer) needs to be fixed.

All in all this is a fabulous game which i would definitely recommend to my friends. 10/10
